channel.title: Upgrading Computer Parts
channel.description:
I'm trying to help my grandfather update his computer parts, because it's about 5 years old and he wants a faster, more efficient computer. But, I'm not that great with making a computer. For now, he just wants a better processor. Right now, he has an [url=http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16819115037]Intel Core 2 Duo E8400[/url] processor and a [url=http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16813128364]GIGABYTE GA-EP45C-UD3R[/url] motherboard.
My question is, will this [url=http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16819116504]Intel Core i5-3570K[/url] processor work with this [url=http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16813131819]ASUS P8Z77-V PRO[/url] motherboard?

item.title: Upgrading Computer Parts
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

holylouis:

not if he had the second as a back up but im speaking as a new slate harddrive in case the first one plays out i usually keep my stuff on flash drives and extranal hard drives so itd be simple for me to do with the new slate drive

He would only need one, backup = hard drive cloning…

Read full topic

not if he had the second as a back up but im speaking as a new slate harddrive in case the first one plays out i usually keep my stuff on flash drives and extranal hard drives so itd be simple for me to do with the new slate drive

item.title: Upgrading Computer Parts
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

3lv3n snip3r:

Another question. He wants to install Windows 7 OEM onto his computer, but he has 2 hard drives in it. The main is the one he uses, and the second one is basically a backup if the first one fails. Right now, he has Windows Vista on both of them. I was wondering if I can install Windows 7 OEM onto both hard drives under one license since they’re both in the same computer.

You can, read this link; I’m sure it’ll answer your questions - http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2421302,00.asp .

holylouis:

this is my area of expertise where yours is programming you could ghost the main hard drive but ud need 2 product keys of course but what id do is make the secondary a recovery backup soo if one harddrive fails ull be able to recover your data by using the secondary…i hope this helps.also its pretty much what muroth said just alot more detailed i suppose

He wouldn’t need two keys since both drives are in the same system.

Read full topic

item.title: Upgrading Computer Parts
item.dc:creator: @holylouis holylouis
item.description:
@holylouis wrote:

this is my area of expertise where yours is programming you could ghost the main hard drive but ud need 2 product keys of course but what id do is make the secondary a recovery backup soo if one harddrive fails ull be able to recover your data by using the secondary…i hope this helps.also its pretty much what muroth said just alot more detailed i suppose

Read full topic

item.title: Upgrading Computer Parts
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

[quote=“3lv3n snip3r, post:6, topic:535523”][quote author=Loveandpower link=topic=654332.msg4383830#msg4383830 date=1384548014]

Another question. He wants to install Windows 7 OEM onto his computer, but he has 2 hard drives in it. The main is the one he uses, and the second one is basically a backup if the first one fails. Right now, he has Windows Vista on both of them. I was wondering if I can install Windows 7 OEM onto both hard drives under one license since they’re both in the same computer.
[/quote]Now that, I am not 100% sure on. I’m pretty sure in a later Windows Update they somehow “register” that key via your bios? ( Don’t quote me on that) Just from a general point of view though one license per copy so legally speaking no.

Edit: It shouldn’t really matter though anyway if one is a backup it’s not like it will be used a lot will it?

I suppose, but he just wants to make sure that he can do that. Can he mirror the hard drives after he installs Windows 7 on the first one?[/quote]

Just make backups to the extra HDD, it’d be fine. If you’re worried just make recovery discs.

Read full topic

item.title: Upgrading Computer Parts
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“3lv3n snip3r, post:6, topic:535523”][quote author=Loveandpower link=topic=654332.msg4383830#msg4383830 date=1384548014]

Another question. He wants to install Windows 7 OEM onto his computer, but he has 2 hard drives in it. The main is the one he uses, and the second one is basically a backup if the first one fails. Right now, he has Windows Vista on both of them. I was wondering if I can install Windows 7 OEM onto both hard drives under one license since they’re both in the same computer.
[/quote]Now that, I am not 100% sure on. I’m pretty sure in a later Windows Update they somehow “register” that key via your bios? ( Don’t quote me on that) Just from a general point of view though one license per copy so legally speaking no.

Edit: It shouldn’t really matter though anyway if one is a backup it’s not like it will be used a lot will it?

I suppose, but he just wants to make sure that he can do that. Can he mirror the hard drives after he installs Windows 7 on the first one?[/quote]I doubt he would ever use anything like this but you can always “mirror” the disks like so

http://www.thegeekstuff.com/2010/08/raid-levels-tutorial/

Besides using Raid 1 I don’t know of any other way sorry. Not really my forte.

Read full topic

Right now, he has Windows Vista on both of them. I was wondering if I can install Windows 7 OEM onto both hard drives under one license since they’re both in the same computer.
[/quote]Now that, I am not 100% sure on. I’m pretty sure in a later Windows Update they somehow “register” that key via your bios? ( Don’t quote me on that) Just from a general point of view though one license per copy so legally speaking no.

Edit: It shouldn’t really matter though anyway if one is a backup it’s not like it will be used a lot will it?[/quote]
I suppose, but he just wants to make sure that he can do that. Can he mirror the hard drives after he installs Windows 7 on the first one?

item.title: Upgrading Computer Parts
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

-Nothing:

Yes. LGA1155 socket processor goes into LGA1155 socket motherboard.

edit: any particular reason why 3rd gen? there is a 4th gen now

Read full topic

item.description:

Yes. LGA1155 socket processor goes into LGA1155 socket motherboard.
